I know no one will read this but I'll write it anyway! I remember finding this video 6 years ago after breaking up with my ex. At the time I was really heartbroken and listened to this video many many times. But with the passage of time I grew to realise that that breakup was the best thing to ever to happen to me! I was a very immature, emotionally insecure, and latched on to that relationship that should have ended so long before or perhaps never should have started, but if we didn't experience all the difficult times then, my life may not be where it is now - happy! Thanks Angela wherever you are.

Whenever I hear this song I think of my one and only, my touch footy middle partner MC Mcleod, the goose to my maverick, the obi wan of Gold Coast touch. We spent many years rucking through the middle, performing the pop play and basically dominating at Owen park touch fields. When I found out he was moving overseas I knew I would no longer experience the pure ecstasy of performing the perfect ruck followed by a pop play and embracing midfield to celebrate our success while ignoring all others. I hear this song and reminisce, I can still  hear our opponents shouting "he is dummy half he can't score" followed by the ref declaring "no he's not", if I close my eyes and simply listen to James blunts lyrics here. I will forever cherish those moments where we would retire to the clubhouse to tell tales of our conquest as all those who were lucky enough to be seated nearby listened in to catch a glimpse of perfection. This song is about a girl Blunt dated, but he wrote it years after the relationship ended. When he appeared on the UK show Songbook, Blunt explained: "I guess it's a realization that you'll never be with someone, but the frustration that they are still alive and out there in the world. It can be an incredibly painful idea - I sat with the song for quite a long time. But for me, it's probably my most personal song. Whereas 'You're Beautiful' is about a moment, one second in time of passing that person, the song 'Goodbye My Lover' is about a lifetime's worth of emotion, the fact that that relationship is over, and that life continues. And yeah, it's the most personal song on Back To Bedlam."

This song is about a girl Blunt dated, but he wrote it years after the relationship ended. When he appeared on the UK show Songbook, Blunt explained: "I guess it's a realization that you'll never be with someone, but the frustration that they are still alive and out there in the world. It can be an incredibly painful idea - I sat with the song for quite a long time. But for me, it's probably my most personal song. Whereas 'You're Beautiful' is about a moment, one second in time of passing that person, the song 'Goodbye My Lover' is about a lifetime's worth of emotion, the fact that that relationship is over, and that life continues. And yeah, it's the most personal song on Back To Bedlam."

SONG FACTS: https://www.songfacts.com/facts/james-blunt/goodbye-my-lover  This song is about a girl Blunt dated, but he wrote it years after the relationship ended. When he appeared on the UK show Songbook, Blunt explained: "I guess it's a realization that you'll never be with someone, but the frustration that they are still alive and out there in the world. It can be an incredibly painful idea - I sat with the song for quite a long time. But for me, it's probably my most personal song. Whereas 'You're Beautiful' is about a moment, one second in time of passing that person, the song 'Goodbye My Lover' is about a lifetime's worth of emotion, the fact that that relationship is over, and that life continues. And yeah, it's the most personal song on Back To Bedlam." James Blunt lived with actress Carrie Fisher while he recorded Back To Bedlam; he met her through a family friend. In the Radio Times February 10, 2006, James Blunt described how he recorded this song in Carrie Fisher's bathroom: "For 'Goodbye My Lover,' we needed a piano. There wasn't one in the home studio we recorded in but Carrie had one in her bathroom. So I said, Let's get the home studio and spend the night in there. It was a good acoustic - that's why people sing in the shower. And it sounds great to me - that's what's on the album." If you think the person Blunt is singing about in this song is dead, you're not the only one; Blunt says he gets asked that a lot. He says the girl he's singing about is very much alive, but the grieving in the song gives the impression of death. This was the fourth single from Back to Bedlam, and in the UK it caused a bit of Blunt-fatigue. In May 2006, the UK radio station Essex FM banned this and all of Blunt's other songs because "We appreciate his success but we need a break." A 2006 UK survey by The Bereavement Register revealed this to be the year's most requested funeral song. Carrie Fisher was the reason for naming the album Back to Bedlam. "Fisher was my American mother, and a real inspiration," Blunt explained to The London Times. "My first album was called Back to Bedlam because I lived in a madhouse with her. She put a cardboard cutout of herself as Leia outside my room, with her date of birth and date of death on her forehead. I'm trying to remember what the date was, because it was around now - and I remember thinking it was too soon."

Kai Schmidt This song is about a girl Blunt dated, but he wrote it years after the relationship ended. When he appeared on the UK show Songbook, Blunt explained: "I guess it's a realization that you'll never be with someone, but the frustration that they are still alive and out there in the world. It can be an incredibly painful idea - I sat with the song for quite a long time. But for me, it's probably my most personal song. Whereas 'You're Beautiful' is about a moment, one second in time of passing that person, the song 'Goodbye My Lover' is about a lifetime's worth of emotion, the fact that that relationship is over, and that life continues. And yeah, it's the most personal song on Back To Bedlam."

I did this when I went to watch Roger Waters. I recorded some of the cool bits of the actual show, but a couple of times when one of my favourite songs was being played I had to check myself and stop recording. I realised I was recording it to be able to go back and look at, but I was focused on the recording, like watching it through my screen. I put my phone away as soon as I noticed that and just took it for what it was in the moment.

Why the hell would you talk only about the old man when there's a bunch of other people that watched without taking out their phones? I swear some of y'all like to fabricate a story out of everything. But I think this song reminded him of the dying words of the compassionate Captain Miller during World War II who went on a search along with 7 other soldiers including Private Vin Diesel to save him, which was "Earn this, Ryan. Earn it."

Abdulrahman Aladwani This song is about a girl Blunt dated, but he wrote it years after the relationship ended. When he appeared on the UK show Songbook, Blunt explained: "I guess it's a realization that you'll never be with someone, but the frustration that they are still alive and out there in the world. Whereas 'You're Beautiful' is about a moment, one second in time of passing that person, the song 'Goodbye My Lover' is about a lifetime's worth of emotion, the fact that that relationship is over, and that life continues. And yeah, it's the most personal song on Back To Bedlam."

Got "real" balls?  Read on... Got myself a new "hobby horse" today so excuse me folks I need to ride it, here goes... Crying is a natural animal emotion. Humans do it and so do some animals. In humans, it expresses joy or sadness. Ever felt that?  It's natural so don't be afraid of it, let the tears wet your cheeks and when you feel that wetness that'll mean you've reconnected with the earliest version of yourself that ever existed - age 1 day- so celebrate it! If you don't cry, ask yourself this: am I a hard ass?  Am I a ****? Have I become so hard that I no longer feel for myself or others' joy or sadness?  Well,  let me tell you this: let's say our average age at death is 75 (in a developed country); so, work out how much longer have you got to "go" before you're "gone"?   Completely GONE - food for worms? (And by the way, I have done this myself and even though I've run the numbers, AND I have a "good" family that loves me (I hope), I'd say I have 10 good years and then within another 30 I'll be forgotten, pretty much an annual visit at the graveyard - if I'm lucky.  Therefore, if you have 20 years left, and I'm sorry if that really means you have 10 "good years" left, well surely it means just don't fuck around? Ask yourself what are you gonna do with them? Hate? Pity? Reconnect with that brother, sister, son, daughter, whoever it is ... with tech today you have NO EXCUSE not to track them down even if you have to pay for it. Just don't feel sorry for yourself...cos nobody will see that and it's pointless.  Isn't your life worth more? You only have one that we "know" of for sure. Time is an "asset" like money - some have it, others don't. "Spend" time rather than "wasting" time in the same way you like to "spend" money rather than "wasting" money. Spend time on helping you be you, a better version of you and helping other people.  If you see that crying is "natural", the word will be better because you will have joined the "circle" of humanity that is awake to all the above.   For men: crying is not weakness, on the contrary! Building muscles in the gym is fine, go get them!  (But I've met so many lonely body builders!) Beers with mates are the same (are the beers joyous or just weekend escapism?)   Learn to appreciate that crying is natural so please - for your sake, not mine, just "tune in" to your emotions and don't be afraid  to "BE YOU" You have limited time to BE YOU! So, decide if you want to subscribe to BS or subscribe to your happiness.  Which is it?  Go to bed, make tomorrow a new beginning but before you go to bed do 2 things: first say this RIGHT NOW:  " I've wasted time looking for "greatness" in others. I was going to copy it.  I failed because I have the wrong thinking - their greatness is theirs, not mine.  So, now I know, I understand! I'm not gong to waste time with that no more!"  Great!   Now write this and put it where you'll see it first thing in the morning (you know where that is and make sure you can see it because it will make you the best version of yourself that you have ever seen!):                                                """""Iâ€™m going go inside myself and get my greatness out of ME!""""""  Say this in the mirror with certainty! And I can promise you this: the "small big men in this youtube room will "excuse themselves and disappear into nothingness!

This song is about a girl Blunt dated, but he wrote it years after the relationship ended. When he appeared on the UK show Songbook, Blunt explained: "I guess it's a realization that you'll never be with someone, but the frustration that they are still alive and out there in the world. It can be an incredibly painful idea - I sat with the song for quite a long time. But for me, it's probably my most personal song. Whereas 'You're Beautiful' is about a moment, one second in time of passing that person, the song 'Goodbye My Lover' is about a lifetime's worth of emotion, the fact that that relationship is over, and that life continues. And yeah, it's the most personal song on Back To Bedlam."

Can I just dive right in and give you my thoughts on the line everyone is quoting in these comments? "You can't break my spirit, it's my dreams you take" is so SO powerful...and I feel I went through one of those dark places so I think I can somewhat relate. I think it contains both the knowledge that, yes, life will go on and you will find joy and maybe love and maybe even true love and fulfillment again... But until your mind ALWAYS puts the new partner in your dreams, both at day and at night, until they become your desire in every moment and every fantasy, they are who you expect to see when you wake up and who you expect to hear when being called by yur favorite nickname...until that happens, you will ALWAYS miss them and wonder how or why or what could be. Your hopes for the future will always have that special someone in them. They become manifested in your head as "the one" and until there is another one, nothing seems to make total sense, nothing ever feels 100%, it's never "just like a dream" with someone else and your dreams wilt and die without that person refreshing and improving upon them again and again with their sheer presence.  It's not just that you lose someone you needed, you lose all the plans and hopes and wishes, all your future and in a way even your past because who wants to hear all the great stories you shared after you split? Nobody, they die slower but they do. In that way, it all falls apart and your dreams do the same. No man dreams of living in a great house and live a great live alone, the right woman is the most essential element of that "arriving" where you want to be. You can have a distinct taste in houses or holiday destinations, but SHE makes the house a home, she makes seeing another place a vacation.

Dave Roberts This song is about a girl Blunt dated, but he wrote it years after the relationship ended. When he appeared on the UK show Songbook, Blunt explained: "I guess it's a realization that you'll never be with someone, but the frustration that they are still alive and out there in the world. It can be an incredibly painful idea - I sat with the song for quite a long time. But for me, it's probably my most personal song. Whereas 'You're Beautiful' is about a moment, one second in time of passing that person, the song 'Goodbye My Lover' is about a lifetime's worth of emotion, the fact that that relationship is over, and that life continues. And yeah, it's the most personal song on Back To Bedlam."

You have been the one for me.  I'm so hollow, baby, I'm so hollow. I'm so, I'm so, I'm so hollow

There was a boy I used to know... he was from Oxford, Bloxham to be precise. We used to have a long distance relationship, but for some reason it was the strongest out of any. I would go visit him and the time we spend together felt timeless... and at a time when I was too naive to appreciate what I had, I under valued him at the time and didn't make the best decisions. I ended up losing him and every word sung in this song literally brought me to tears, as nothing ever spoke out to me in such a way, right into my very soul inside me.  I just wanted to say thankyou Jack for every single day that we shared time together and gave up a piece of ourselves for eachother. I will never ever forget you, and you will ALWAYS be the one for me. </3  Peter.

I know I'm a random stranger on the internet, but I wanted to tell you that I'm somebody that deals with depression every single day. While I don't know what's hurt you, or how deeply you've been wounded, I just wanted you to know that I hope you can overcome that pain. Each and every one of us in the world can reach out and try to lift one another up, even when we don't feel that we can take another step ourselves. I can't claim that this song speaks to me, as I've never gone that far with anyone, but I did had a girl that I grew up with, and only discovered that the feeling strongest I had for her was love, after she and her family had moved away, with no way of contacting her. 21 years later and it still hurts. I guess what I'm trying to say is keep going, and push past the pain in any way you can without destroying yourself. If you can still be sad, if you can still feel pain, then there's still hope for you. I wish you the best.

Â @roadrunner4449Â  Well he did, he wrote it with someone.

Â @roadrunner4449Â  James wrote it while he was staying at Carrie Fisher's house in LA.  Sacha Skarbek later added to it and got a co-writer credit (the same as he did for "You're Beautiful" and Miley Cyrus's "Wrecking Ball"), but the basics go back to James.  Artists performing "personal" songs is different for each one.  Roger Waters has been doing Pink Floyd's "Brain Damage" (the track from "Dark Side of the Moon" with the title phrase in the chorus) for over 40 years, and there's a lot of unearned guilt in those lyrics.  (It's Waters imagining Floyd founder Syd Barrett accusing Roger of not being there during Syd's mental breakdown troubles and subsequent lobotomy [which obviously left Syd in no condition to make such charges] and warning Roger that one of these days, he'll fall apart the same way and "I'll see you on the dark side of the moon.")  OTOH, Taylor Swift has never been able to make herself perform "Breathe", which is allegedly Taylor apologizing to her ex-fiddle player, Emily, for not fighting hard enough to keep her in the band when management kicked her out because (allegedly) Taylor and Emily were dating and they were worried about TS's image (again, allegedly).  So, all those "I'm sorry" lyrics have never been sung live.  It's different for everyone.  Maybe every time James performs this song, he heals the pain of losing the lover who left him "so hollow".  At least, I hope so.  (Well, I hope he's over it completely by now.  But you never know.)

James Blunt, a gifted musician. All his songs are touching but also hurtful at the same time. I think everyone has been through what he had to experience. A while ago, I ended the relationship with my girlfriend. I saw no other possibility. It felt as if you were struck by a bullet in the heart. After a few days we wrote to each other. I thought we should not let go and look for new partners. But actually I wanted to be back with her and enjoy her love, which she had not given me at that time. A few sentences later we started fighting and broke off the contact for the time being. And now she hates me, sends me pictures with her new friend and how happy she is with him. I, however, lie in my bed listening to the music that reminds me of that time. I think that James would tell us that we humans, we love should hold, even if it's hard. Because these people can change something in your life that you could not create. Sorry if the translation is not 100%. I'm just a student from Germany.

GOODBYE MY LOVER by JAMES BLUNT This song is about a girl Blunt dated, but he wrote it years after the relationship ended. When he appeared on the UK show Songbook, Blunt explained: "I guess it's a realization that you'll never be with someone, but the frustration that they are still alive and out there in the world. It can be an incredibly painful idea - I sat with the song for quite a long time. But for me, it's probably my most personal song. Whereas 'You're Beautiful' is about a moment, one second in time of passing that person, the song 'Goodbye My Lover' is about a lifetime's worth of emotion, the fact that that relationship is over, and that life continues. And yeah, it's the most personal song on Back To Bedlam."

The lyrics of this song sort of seem like an apology to me. "Did I disappoint you or let you down. Should I be feeling guilty or let the judges frown" and "I saw the end before it begun, I saw you were blinded and I knew I had won" kinda seems like James may have taken advantage of the trust he had with a presumed lover. I hear a lot of regret and pain in the words. He understands that it's the end but he is still there for her even after admitting his fault and realising things won't be the same. "So I took what's mine by eternal right" He took the blame perhaps? Only part I cannot determine is "My heart was blinded by you" Since the lyrics point towards a past tense it's hard to determine whether or not this was at the start of the relationship and he fell out of love or he loved her all the way through until he got over her.  Maybe if I completely contradict myself and say that "Did I disappoint you or let you down. Should I be feeling guilty or let the judges frown" is a literal question as he is confused as to why she left him. I don't know man, it's 4:11AM and i'm just trying to occupy myself and just so happened to stumbled across this video. Also, people holding their mobile phones during this man's performance is absolutely preposterous.  Whether or not you agree, feel free to express your opinions.  P.S. Obviously he has been hurt in the past. There's no way someone can sing a song with that much passion if it didn't have such a profound effect on them. Generally an effect of that magnitude is negative and results in pain.

I can't stop watching/listening to this performance... it blows my mind how he can dig up all that emotion even though it's such an old song he's undoubtedly sang so many times over before. And it also just leaves me aghast how much passion he put into this performance.  Just amazing... really inspirational.  Watching this makes me cry every time despite having seen it before. I guess I'm just an overly emotional sap, but hey. Just seeing his tortured expressions make me want to give him a big hug. Allowing yourself to connect that much with your emotions whilst keeping on performing like that (especially singing and playing at the same time) is an art form and takes a lot of skill.
